. The first time your user logins into your app (`$cordovaFacebook.login()`) you'll have to put in **all** of the permissions you require for your app. The modal will open asking the user to allow FB to be used in your app (you can't get around this).

After that your app will be _forever_ logged into facebook. If your user closes your app and then reopens it, you should check if the user is currently logged (`$cordovaFacebook.getLoginStatus()`) in **before** asking to login (which is not necessary if `getLoginStatus` results in `true`). That way the modal never pops up again.

Then to call the `api`, make sure that the permissions are `= []`, so that the modal doesn't come up again. If you need extra permissions that you did not include in the login, then you'll have to include them in the `api` call, and it will bring up the modal again.

You might be right about the promise resolving only once when the `$rootScope.$on(...)` event is fired.

In fact a promise doesn't make sense here at all. Promises are meant for an asynchronous event, whereas with `$broadcast`, the `$on` event is fired and the resulting function is immediately called right after. Therefore the only solution for this would be a callback:

```
return {
  listenNotificationReceived: function(callback) {
    $rootScope.$on("pushNotificationReceived", callback());
  }
}
```

And usage:

```
myApp.controller(function($scope, $pushPlugin) {
  $scope.myArr = [];

  $pushPlugin.listenNotificationReceived(function () {
    // do something now that the notification has been received
  })
});
```

. The first time your user logins into your app (`$cordovaFacebook.login()`) you'll have to put in **all** of the permissions you require for your app. The modal will open asking the user to allow FB to be used in your app (you can't get around this).

After that your app will be _forever_ logged into facebook. If your user closes your app and then reopens it, you should check if the user is currently logged (`$cordovaFacebook.getLoginStatus()`) in **before** asking to login (which is not necessary if `getLoginStatus` results in `true`). That way the modal never pops up again.

Then to call the `api`, make sure that the permissions are `= []`, so that the modal doesn't come up again. If you need extra permissions that you did not include in the login, then you'll have to include them in the `api` call, and it will bring up the modal again.

You might be right about the promise resolving only once when the `$rootScope.$on(...)` event is fired.

In fact a promise doesn't make sense here at all. Promises are meant for an asynchronous event, whereas with `$broadcast`, the `$on` event is fired and the resulting function is immediately called right after. Therefore the only solution for this would be a callback:

```
return {
  listenNotificationReceived: function(callback) {
    $rootScope.$on("pushNotificationReceived", callback());
  }
}
```

And usage:

```
myApp.controller(function($scope, $pushPlugin) {
  $scope.myArr = [];

  $pushPlugin.listenNotificationReceived(function () {
    // do something now that the notification has been received
  })
});
```

Alias the function ([`localNotification.js:103`](https://github.com/driftyco/ng-cordova/blob/master/src/plugins/localNotification.js#L103))

``` js
onclick: window.plugin.notification.local.onclick,

The usage of this would be how you expected it would be:
`$cordovaLocalNotification.onclick = function (id, state, json) {`

---

Or use Angular events for it:

``` js
var scope = $rootScope.$new();

// assign all functions to the scope
scope. getTriggeredIds = function () { ... }

// use angular events
window.plugin.notification.local.onclick = function (id, state, json) {
    scope.$broadcast('click', id, state, json)
};

return scope;
```

The usage would be like:

``` js
$cordovaLocalNotification.$on('click', function (event, id, state, json) {
   console.log(event, id, state, json);
});
```

navigator.languages = ["en-US", "en"]
navigator.language = "en-US"

Safari:
navigator.languages = undefined
navigator.language = "en-US"

Firefox Regular & DE : 
navigator.languages = ["en-US", "en"]
navigator.language = "en-US"

IE
navigator.languages = undefined
navigator.language = "en-US"

angular.module('ngCordova.plugins.myPlugin', [])

            return {
                get: function() {
                    var q = $q.defer();
                    $window.plugins.myPlugin.get(function (result) {
                        q.resolve(result);
                    }, function(error) {
                        q.reject(error);
                    });
                    return q.promise;
                }
            };
        }]);

. @kylelib  If you're using Angular (which ngCordova depends on), then you simply use the DI syntax to have $window be injected:

```
angular.module('ngCordova.plugins.myPlugin', [])
        .factory('$cordovaMyPlugin', ['$q', '$window', function ($q, $window) {
            return {
                get: function() {
                    var q = $q.defer();
                    $window.plugins.myPlugin.get(function (result) {
                        q.resolve(result);
                    }, function(error) {
                        q.reject(error);
                    });
                    return q.promise;
                }
            };
        }]);
```

That's true; and that's why I want people to give us PRs instead of just raising issues.  It's easy to say, "you need to do this", it's harder to say, "This is an issue; and I don't know how to help, but I want to."

ngCordova only succeeds if we do the latter.  If this were a project with one or two plugins, that'd be one thing -- but ngCordova supports lots of plugin wrappers for 64+ plugins; not all of which have community support behind them.

Submodules mean not knowing when there's an unstable build; and with the free time we have, it can't be spent tracking down unstable builds because a submodule was updated and we have no Issue tracking/commit tracking in this repository to see what changed upstream. michelhabib:
Good question!
There is always a possibility that Cordova is not ready, or any of the plugins is not properly installed or maybe it is installed on the platform but it failed during initialization.
it is always a good practice when writing for Cordova to first check that window.cordova is available and for each plugin to check that it is available before running further code, so you avoid getting javascript errors on null objects, which will stop execution of the code and the user cannot easily understand what is happening without a proper catch.

for most of the cases, it helps during the debugging when the developer is changing environments, platforms, etc... which is a common scenario. For few other cases, it ensures that you can catch exceptions when plugin initialization fails and expose them to the user in a friendly way - or even report it using any reporting tool like analytics or flurry.

#### Here's why

The iOS implementation of the plugin uses selectors that aren't supported anymore:
https://github.com/xcodeguy/plugins-application-preferences/blob/master/src/ios/AGApplicationPreferences.h#L18-19

which makes CordovaLib always return false here:
https://github.com/apache/cordova-ios/blob/master/CordovaLib/Classes/CDVCommandQueue.m#L194-L196

It looks like @pellekrogholt was on the right track searching for an alternative, but his pull request was eventually reversed back to this old plugin. Why? The plugin he chose uses supported selectors with `CDVInvokedUrlCommand`:

https://github.com/pellekrogholt/AppPreferences/blob/master/src/ios/applicationPreferences.h#L18-L19

I'm guessing it probably worked for a short while until it was reversed.

overwrite the native browser's `window.open` function, causing the facebook
login to return error X-Frame-Options configured to DENY, because we can't
load it with iframes, just actually tabs, browser windows, popup. To reset
to default behaviour, just delete the object:

``` js
document.addEventListener("deviceready", function () {
  delete window.open;
}, false);

Android build it must be ignored.

```
if (cordova.platformId === 'browser') {
  document.addEventListener("deviceready", function () {
    delete window.open;
  }, false);
}
```

aogilvie:
As I commented on the PR (https://github.com/Wizcorp/phonegap-facebook-plugin/pull/880 - thanks btw!) from @pbernasconi if you wish to run your application in browser mode you must add the browser platform;
`cordova platform browser`
This acts like any other platform. Apache Cordova team has created a new `cordova.js` library specifically for browser to allow plugins to help bridge missing APIs when running in the browser.

I think the PhoneGap/Cordova workflow is not very well explained on their website so i'll explain how I think the correct way to develop a PhoneGap/Cordova application.

After creating your Cordova application and adding your platforms your directory structure should look a little something like this;
- platforms
  - android  <-- test and publish your application in here for Android
  - browser <-- test and publish your application in here for the browser
  - ios         <-- test and publish your application in here for iOS
- www  <-- edit your files here
- hooks
- plugins

After editing your files there is a "compile process" similar to any other programming workflow usually done by an IDE such as Xcode, Eclipse etc.
To "compile" your project you would run `cordova build` command. You can re-compile for a specific platform with `cordova build browser` `cordova build ios` for example.

If running a command each time a file is modified sounds like a pain do;

First start your browser app;
`cordova run browser`

This starts Chrome with special flags and loads (`<your app dir>/platforms/browser/www/index.html`).

Next we'll install a file system listening script;

`gem install listen`

create `listen.rb` file at your project root and add:

```
require 'listen'
listener = Listen.to('www') do |modified, added, removed|
  if modified.size > 0
    puts "Files modified: #{modified}"
    `cordova build browser`
  end
  if added.size > 0
    puts "Files added: #{added}"
    `cordova build browser`
  end
  if removed.size > 0
    puts "Files Removed: #{removed}"
    `cordova build browser`
  end
end
listener.start
sleep
```

The above code will monitor the `www` directory and build the browser platform each time something changes.

Now run `ruby listen.rb`

And behold... magic will happen. Just refresh Chrome to see your changes.

21.03.2015, 18:13, "Robbin Habermehl" notifications@github.com:Recent refactoring of $cordovaFile resolved the issue that's described here. The original problem was that a file system was requested with storage type "1", while for Library/NoCloud that should've been "4". Now the requestFileSystem method isn't used any longer which resolves this issue.

Unfortunately these changes haven't been released for usage with Bower, but you can use it in your app already. Just include ngCordova like this in Bower:

{
  "dependencies": {
    "ngCordova": "driftyco/ng-cordova#b5e612d109a90afa7edcbaf63406a41b9912eba6"
  }
}

Also make sure that the extra file systems get included by adding the following to config.xml:

  <preference name="iosExtraFilesystems" value="library,library-nosync,documents,documents-nosync,cache,bundle,root"/>

Then use the methods of $cordovaFile as described in the docs, for instance:

$cordovaFile.checkFile(window.cordova.file.dataDirectory, 'file.ext').then(function() {
  ...
});

I've only tested this with the latest version of the cordoba-file-plugin, so just to be sure you could remove and add it:

cordova plugin remove org.apache.cordova.file
cordova plugin add org.apache.cordova.file

21.03.2015, 18:13, "Robbin Habermehl" notifications@github.com:Recent refactoring of $cordovaFile resolved the issue that's described here. The original problem was that a file system was requested with storage type "1", while for Library/NoCloud that should've been "4". Now the requestFileSystem method isn't used any longer which resolves this issue.

Unfortunately these changes haven't been released for usage with Bower, but you can use it in your app already. Just include ngCordova like this in Bower:

{
  "dependencies": {
    "ngCordova": "driftyco/ng-cordova#b5e612d109a90afa7edcbaf63406a41b9912eba6"
  }
}

Also make sure that the extra file systems get included by adding the following to config.xml:

  <preference name="iosExtraFilesystems" value="library,library-nosync,documents,documents-nosync,cache,bundle,root"/>

Then use the methods of $cordovaFile as described in the docs, for instance:

$cordovaFile.checkFile(window.cordova.file.dataDirectory, 'file.ext').then(function() {
  ...
});

I've only tested this with the latest version of the cordoba-file-plugin, so just to be sure you could remove and add it:

cordova plugin remove org.apache.cordova.file
cordova plugin add org.apache.cordova.file

RobbinHabermehl:
Recent refactoring of `$cordovaFile` resolved the issue that's described here. The original problem was that a file system was requested with storage type "1", while for `Library/NoCloud` that should've been "4". Now the `requestFileSystem` method isn't used any longer which resolves this issue.

Unfortunately these changes haven't been released for usage with Bower, but you can use it in your app already. Just include ngCordova like this in Bower:

```
{
  "dependencies": {
    "ngCordova": "driftyco/ng-cordova#b5e612d109a90afa7edcbaf63406a41b9912eba6"
  }
}
```

Also make sure that the extra file systems get included by adding the following to `config.xml`:

```
  <preference name="iosExtraFilesystems" value="library,library-nosync,documents,documents-nosync,cache,bundle,root"/>
```

Then use the methods of `$cordovaFile` as described in the docs, for instance:

```
$cordovaFile.checkFile(window.cordova.file.dataDirectory, 'file.ext').then(function() {
  ...
});
```

I've only tested this with the latest version of the `cordoba-file-plugin`, so just to be sure you could remove and add it:

```
cordova plugin remove org.apache.cordova.file
cordova plugin add org.apache.cordova.file
```

mattheworres:
So, I just figured this out on Android, and it'd be really helpful if they added this to the guide.
1. Follow the main ngCordova guidelines: test on-device only, and wrap your plugin calls to ensure the device is ready
2. The ngCordova guide (despite being empty) is still wrong. ngCordova is using floatinghotpot's original admob plugin here: `https://github.com/floatinghotpot/cordova-plugin-admob`
3. In addition to having ngCordova installed, ensure you also add floatinghotpot's admob plugin itself :(ngCordova just acts as a wrapper to allow it to be injected into your Angular app): `cordova plugin add https://github.com/floatinghotpot/cordova-plugin-admob.git`
4. Ensure your AdMob account has a few ad units setup for whatever platforms you target.
5. After setting up the proper admobid object with banner/interstitial IDs for the platform you're on, call `createBannerView` with options as needed

``` javascript
$cordovaAdMob.createBannerView({
        publisherId: admobid.banner,
        bannerAtTop: false, // set to true, to put banner at top
        overlap: false, // set to true, to allow banner overlap webview
        offsetTopBar: false, // set to true to avoid ios7 status bar overlap
        isTesting: false, // receiving test ad
        autoShow: true // auto show interstitial ad when loaded
      });
```
. So, its worth noting the options I pass `createBannerView` doesn't include the interstitial ads.

This version of floatinghotpot's AdMob plugin leaves quite a bit to be desired, as it seems he's moved on to the re-written "pro" plugin instead. But, it's AdMob, and it works. So, there's that.

See this example page for some more ideas:

https://github.com/floatinghotpot/cordova-plugin-admob/blob/master/test/index.html

. @ionSpark Thanks for your answer. I actually figured it out a few days after posting the question. Turns out this can be controlled via plugin.xml quite easily on the <js-module> element.
. You specify one or more `<clobbers>` nodes in the `<js-module>` node of the plugin.xml for your plugin. It is documented [here ](https://cordova.apache.org/docs/en/latest/plugin_ref/spec.html#js-module)

For example, to attach a plugin named _myPlugin_ defined in _www/myPlugin.js_ to both `$window` and `$window.cordova.plugins` use the following:

``` xml
  <!-- JavaScript interface attached to $window -->
  <js-module src="www/myPlugin.js" name="myPlugin">
    <clobbers target="myPlugin" />
    <clobbers target="cordova.plugins.myPlugin" />
  </js-module>
```

From this point on you can reference your plugin in those two locations, `$window.myPlugin` or `$window.cordova.plugins.myPlugin`.

mobajm:
I spent hours today struggling with this issue. Geolocation kept timing out on android 5.0 and 5.1. Installing version 1.0 of the cordova geolocation plugin (I had version 0.3.x before) did it for me.

According to [https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CB-5977](this link), this version only adds the required location permissions to the AndroidManifest.xml file, and leaves the rest of the work to the Web geolocation API instead of the device's native one.

So, 

``` shell
cordova plugin rm org.apache.cordova.geolocation
cordova plugin add cordova-plugin-geolocation
```

Then just use the Web API : 

``` js
navigator.geolocation.getCurrentPosition(
    successCallback,
    errorCallback,
    options
);
```

Hope this helps

barryvdh:
You could think about splitting up the repositories and let Bower (or npm etc) handle it.

So 1 'core' package with just the shared stuff. Then for each plugin a seperate repository, which requires the core package.

This does make it more work to maintain, because every repo has a lot of files, but it make it easy to install with Bower. Eg. I just want the push plugin:

`$ bower install ng-cordova-push`

That loads the push plugin + core. If I later on also want geo: `$ bower install ng-cordova-geo` or something.

If push moves to a different Cordova plugin, we can use a new major version. `1.x` for the old version, `2.x` for the new one. If there is a breaking change in one of the plugins, we can just require them seperate.

This large repo is easy to maintain, but you can't just set a fixed version on just 1 plugin..
. Yeah you would get more repo's to watch, but the amount of issues would probably be the same ;)
You could also add more maintainers for just 1 repo, keep the issues organised per plugin and set an example so that other people can just make their own plugins on their own repo if they want.

Right. Figured it out finally.

For those who may run into this issue in the future, on linux and mac this key hash will be pulled from

``` bash
~/.android/debug.keystore
```

In order to find out what the hash key will be, you may use

``` bash
keytool -exportcert -alias androiddebugkey -keystore ~/.android/debug.keystore | openssl sha1 -binary | openssl base64
```

Then proceed to developers.facebook.com, select your app, include Android as platform, and include the value given by the previous command in the 'Key Hashes' input. 

You're good to go!

andreialecu:
I had similar problems to @scripterkaran with the promise never resolving on iOS and they were caused by some sort of incompatibility with the new push plugin and the old one. 

If I would install the new plugin while the deprecated one was still there, and then remove the deprecated one, the new one would stop working properly. I could confirm this in the logs from the device, where there would be an error about `Plugin 'PushPlugin' not found or is not a CDVPlugin`. I noticed something was wrong after putting a break point in the `init` function of `PushPlugin.m` in XCode and not seeing it trigger.

What did it for me was removing both plugins and then just adding the new one. It may also help removing the iOS platform and re-adding it.

I managed to write base64 data by transfer the data to Blob and pass the Blob as the data.

```
 $cordovaFile.writeFile(path, "test.jpeg", dataURItoBlob(dataURI), true)
 dataURItoFile = (dataURI) ->
    byteString = atob(dataURI.split(',')[1])
    mimeString = dataURI.split(',')[0].split(':')[1].split(';')[0]
    array = []
    i = 0
    while i < byteString.length
      array.push(byteString.charCodeAt(i))
      i++
    new Blob([new Uint8Array(array)], 'type': mimeString)
```

I run the `$cordovaFile.checkFile` in a similar manner and `requestedPath` is set to the file, the whole function works. Seems like there's something wrong with the parameters of the write function? I took the function specs from here: 

http://ngcordova.com/docs/plugins/file/

Also, the reason for the failing to create a file is the weird `cdvfile://localhost/persistent` prefix. Why is that needed? With this prefix, the whole path does not exist and fails in the `.m` file, hence returning the error.

```
(lldb) po baseURI.absoluteURL
cdvfile://localhost/persistent

(lldb) po requestedPath
cdvfile://localhost/persistent/Users/me/Library/Developer/CoreSimulator/Devices/8FB2AAA7-1DAB-4D6F-AD9B-044BF019F367/data/Containers/Data/Application/525FB6CF-5BE6-451E-BF6D-A12E1B25CE4A/Documents/FILE_NAME_NOT_PRESENT
```
. I think I now understood and solved it. One should specify filenames only...

- Run your ionic project without SSL using `ionic serve` at port `8100`
- Setup HTTPS proxy at port `8101` to be able to use privacy-critical functions like geolocation
- Connect with your mobile device at `https://proxy-ip:8101`
